importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the current timeline of political action regarding U.S. military engagement in Venezuela.
The date when Sen. Tim Kaine filed the resolution to force a Senate vote on limiting presidential war powers, marking a key moment in the political standoff.
The date when President Trump made public statements about military strikes and covert operations in Venezuela, escalating tensions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 10-day waiting period after filing the resolution before the Senate must take up the legislation, which is a procedural requirement for the vote to occur.

keyTakeAways: Sen. Tim Kaine is leading a bipartisan effort to force a Senate vote on a resolution that would prevent President Trump from unilaterally declaring war on Venezuela.
The resolution is designed to uphold Congress's constitutional power to declare war, countering executive overreach.
President Trump has authorized military strikes in the Caribbean and covert CIA operations in Venezuela, citing drug smuggling concerns.
A previous vote on similar war powers in the Caribbean failed 48-51, but two Republicans (Rand Paul and Lisa Murkowski) supported it, indicating some bipartisan resistance.
Senators Adam Schiff and Rand Paul co-sponsored the new resolution, showing bipartisan support among key lawmakers.
The U.S. government has not shared evidence or identities of those killed in at least five military strikes since September, raising concerns about transparency and legality.
At least 27 people have been reported killed in these strikes, but identities remain unshared, fueling public and congressional skepticism.
There is uncertainty about whether enough Republican votes will support the resolution, despite past Republican support for similar war powers measures.
The resolution aims to require public debate and congressional approval before any land or sea military operations in Venezuela.
Sen. Rand Paul has criticized the military actions as setting a dangerous precedent for shooting first without congressional oversight.

namedEntities.name: Tim Kaine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Senator from Virginia, Democratic Party, leading the bipartisan effort to force a vote on war powers in Venezuela.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kaine is central to the article as the main proponent of the resolution to limit presidential war powers, advocating for congressional oversight of military actions in Venezuela.

namedEntities.name: Adam Schiff
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Senator from California, Democratic Party, co-sponsor of the war powers resolution.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Schiff joined Kaine in pushing for congressional oversight, showing bipartisan momentum and reinforcing the legitimacy of the resolution.

namedEntities.name: Rand Paul
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Senator from Kentucky, Republican Party, co-sponsor and vocal critic of military strikes in Venezuela.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Paul represents a significant Republican voice opposing executive overreach and emphasizing constitutional checks on war powers.

namedEntities.name: Lisa Murkowski
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Senator from Alaska, Republican Party, supported a previous vote on war powers in the Caribbean.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Murkowski's prior support indicates a potential for broader Republican alignment on limiting executive war actions.

namedEntities.name: President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of the United States, authorized military strikes and covert operations in the Caribbean and Venezuela.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is the central figure whose actions—military strikes and covert operations—are being challenged by Congress, making him a focal point of the political conflict.

namedEntities.name: Venezuela
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: South American nation, target of U.S. military strikes and covert operations under Trump administration.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Venezuela is the geopolitical focus of the military actions and congressional resistance, central to the conflict over executive war powers.

namedEntities.name: Caribbean
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Geographic region where U.S. military strikes have occurred, linked to drug smuggling allegations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Caribbean actions are part of a broader pattern of military operations that prompted earlier congressional votes on war powers.

namedEntities.name: CIA
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. intelligence agency, authorized to conduct covert operations in Venezuela under Trump.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CIA's involvement in Venezuela signals covert action, which is directly challenged by the war powers resolution.

namedEntities.name: Congress
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. legislative body, tasked with declaring war and reviewing executive military actions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Congress is portrayed as a constitutional check on executive power, especially in the context of war decisions involving Venezuela.

summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. Senators Tim Kaine, Adam Schiff, and Rand Paul are pushing to force a Senate vote to prevent President Donald Trump from unilaterally declaring war on Venezuela, citing a surge in military strikes and covert CIA operations in the Caribbean and Venezuela. The resolution, filed by Kaine and co-sponsored by Schiff and Paul, is designed to uphold Congress's constitutional authority to declare war. Trump has authorized at least five military strikes since September, claiming to target drug smuggling, with 27 people reportedly killed—though identities remain unshared. A previous vote on similar war powers in the Caribbean failed narrowly, but bipartisan support from Republicans like Paul and Murkowski shows some resistance. The article highlights concerns over lack of transparency, constitutional overreach, and the potential for escalating military engagement in Venezuela without public debate or legislative approval.
title: Senators Will Force a Vote to Prevent War on Venezuela Without Approval from Congress
